author: lastmjs
content: I think this would be a great idea

author: lastmjs
content: At first I felt the Bitcoiners were making too big a fuss out of nothing...but they have a point. I think Ethereum needs this functionality

author: sky.cactus
content: If I had to take a guess, some explorers are discounting known burnt ETH like ETH at 0 address, ETH lost in provable ways like Parity multisig, etc.

author: lastmjs
content: <@!552133098075193354> How can this be moved forward?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> yeah, adding a proper total supply command to the client seems like a low-cost and reasonable thing to do

author: lastmjs
content: Should this be an addition to the JSON RPC spec? eth_getSupplyAtBlock, similar to what's mentioned above?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think responding reactively to Bitcoin maximalists on Twitter isn't a good use of development resources personally.  üò¨

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> I'd say one client supporting it as an extra feature should be enough

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't believe supply is actually tracked in the clients at the moment. So clients would need to do work to track it, and any explorer or third party tool could do the same out of client I believe?

author: sky.cactus
content: You just need to troll block history and add up ETH reward per block plus uncle reward per block?

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming you ignore burnt/inaccessible ETH.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> yeah, I think you can compute it with just the header chain

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> if you ignore self-suicide burning

author: sky.cactus
content: Feels like we could talk someone not-client-dev to do this work?  If people care, just throw up a little bounty for it?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> sure! Make a gitcoin grant bounty? üòù

author: sky.cactus
content: The effort required is pretty low, no significant skill or specialized knowledge needed.  Just have to look at block reward change history and fork block numbers. I don't think uncle rewards have ever changed?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> uncle rewards are tricky because they depend on inclusion delay

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> uncle rewards changed proportionately to block rewards

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, good point.  Still not worth throwing a senior engineer (basically all core devs) at it IMO.

author: sky.cactus
content: At a traditional company I would task a junior engineer at this, with review/oversight from a senior.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> yeah that sounds reasonable

author: sky.cactus
content: It is a nice self contained project that doesn't need to worry about "correct architectural choices", which is great for a junior.

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, if someone writes a little TypeScript app that speaks JSON-RPC with a client and trolls through block history, i wouldn't mind reviewing it for correctness.

author: sky.cactus
content: Or JS I suppose (though I don't recommend anyone write JS).

author: mandrigin
content: I guess it is also important to have a parameter like ‚Äúsupply at block N‚Äù because otherwise the differences might be explained that some clients were a bit behind, when the calculation was started.

author: lastmjs
content: I think it would be more useful if multiple Ethereum clients came to a standard implementation of the supply at a given block. It will take carefully crafted work to get this to be extremely accurate

author: mandrigin
content: also it will take way longer to implement üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: And implementing it inside of clients requires critical developers to not work on other things.

author: sky.cactus
content: Implementing it as an external app lets us utilize less critical developers or people looking to dip their feet in for the task.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> total supply is just one of many important statistics / aggregates about the chain and there is no reason why it should be expected from clients to provide it

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> clients deliver various extra features whenever they think the users would be happy to see them added but adding total supply as a standard would be an overkill

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> total supply calculation is very heavy - it requires loading all block bodies from genesis

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> headers only contain uncles hash and it is not enough to calculate rewards from it - one needs uncle headers which are only available im block bodies

author: sky.cactus
content: Why do you need uncle headers?  I thought it was just a flat rate for the uncle by age (function of block reward and uncle age)?

author: Deleted User
content: wouldn't the easier to just iterate through the accounts in the state and take the balances?

author: Deleted User
content: then you don't need to know all the rules about uncles etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think it is possible to iterate all accounts in some cases?

author: sky.cactus
content: Particularly, between blocks since the values can change between blocks.

author: Deleted User
content: it depends on what is the purpose of all this

author: sky.cactus
content: The impression I get is that the purpose is to be able to fire back at Bitcoin maximalists on Twitter.  üòñ

author: sky.cactus
content: A trending meme with the BTC maximalists is "on Ethereum, you can't even figure out what the ETH supply is!" and that, apparently is a strong indicator that Ethereum is a scam or something.  ü§∑

author: sky.cactus
content: In reality it is just that "no one really cares enough to calculate the total supply precisely, so we use an estimate instead".  I'm pretty sure everyone here knows that, but you know how Twitter is...

author: sky.cactus
content:
> clients deliver various extra features whenever they think the users would be happy to see them added
<@!489256758989029405> I suspect there are near 0 actual users who want this feature.  My guess is that there was one BTC maximalist who tried to find the answer online (not an Ethereum user) and couldn't, so they started memeing about it.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> it is a trap - build that into the clients and all your users will be looking at the supply ticking up the same way as they look at their DeFi holdings going up 0.00001 every second without analysing economics behind it (re @eth1x_bridge_bot: <Micah> The impression I get is that the purpose is to be able to fire back at Bitcoin maximalists on Twitter.  üòñ)

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> let us add it as part of the eip-1559 and you have an additional PR tool

author: sky.cactus
content: It hurts me deep in my soul that such a tactic would probably work...

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> I can add this feature in a short time, the problem is that calculation will take 2 hours+ (whether you do that by bodies or accounts iteration)

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <tkstanczak> I think that TurboGeth team will add it maybe as they can have a quicker access to the flat state

content: found the Discord channel, how nice

author: tkstanczak
content: probably by the end of next week etherscan will review if their algorithm is right and that is it :) we all know the rough number which is enough in most cases and whenever we need a more detailed value, we know how to calculate it

author: 1n1a5
content: Should burnt ETH be considered as a part of total ETH supply?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <timbeiko> They are just two different metrics: total ETH ever issued (‚Äúissued supply‚Äù) and ETH held in all accounts (‚Äúexisting supply‚Äù). You can then get even more granular than that (i.e. existing supply minus ETH @ 0x0, minus ‚Äúknown locked funds‚Äù, etc.).

author: keccack256
content: <@701536321381990481> it should be part of total supply, not available supply though. Bitcoin has the unspendable outputs not in the utxo sets which makes it easy as gettxoutsetinfo doesn‚Äôt include them, but for burned or selfdestructed ETH it‚Äôs harder in ethereum since there‚Äôs no concept of ‚Äúunspendable‚Äù
